did.unittitle: New York University Archives Collection of Nineteenth-Century Correspondence
did.abstract: New York Universiy Archives serves as the final repository for the historical records of NYU. This collection consists of nineteenth-century correspondence collected by the New York University Archives. The collection contains an 1838 letter relating to financing for the construction of New York University's University Building, and the efforts of then-Attorney General Benjamin Franklin Butler to secure debt relief for the University in that matter.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Robert and Nevine Melikian, August 2017. The accession number associated with this gift is 2019.074

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of nineteenth-century correspondence collected by the New York University Archives. The collection contains an 1838 letter relating to financing for the construction of New York University's University Building, and the efforts of then-Attorney General Benjamin Franklin Butler to secure debt relief for the University in that matter.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: New York Universiy Archives serves as the final repository for the historical records of NYU. Its primary purpose is to document the history of the University and to provide source material for administrators, faculty, students, alumni, and other members of the University community, as well as scholars, authors, and other interested persons who seek to evaluate the impact of the University's activities on the history of American social, cultural, and intellectual development.
